channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: The shimmer of language and experience. (What a tiny book of translations of the same four lines of ancient Chinese poetry has to offer.) https://t.co/7PefW7cTZ5
@davewiner @dsearls …stories for our memoirs…

@davewiner @dsearls Radio’s been magical to me since my dad helped set me up with a crystal radio not too far into the 1960s. Ball games long after bedtime. Transistor radio on the porch. The clear-channel music stations of distant cities, later on.

@davewiner On this list, the AM stations with no restriction after the 50 kw U in the final column are good candidates. We Midwesterners, before the rise of FM, could hear a handful of them fairly often after dark from hundreds of miles away. Hear the Cardinals game beyond Chicago, say.
@davewiner And the list itself: https://t.co/XsWRYh8Mtm
"I realized long ago that there are two separate and very different health-care systems in this country." --Bobbi Dempsey https://t.co/FFdtCwog2a https://t.co/7nTOA0WXsA
“What writing does is allow us to sample each other’s fate.” —Edna O’Brien Also, dessert. Also, heart. https://t.co/oB7tErFkAP via Paul @Holdengraber.
Here’s a game. Photograph a cartoon you like and add something to it. https://t.co/ADbGzQJuAW
@toebean_peets https://t.co/kZtWeSEGaf
With social media, “we are paying with something other than money.” Voice on the NPR show just now, 7:57 am Eastern. Jennifer Egan, it turns out. https://t.co/bvKoH7KdcP
Digital witnessing by refugees--some things a cell phone changes during a most vulnerable and dangerous time in their lives. https://t.co/zIh6Ol0Tgx
Digital witnessing by refugees--some things a cell phone changes during a most vulnerable time in their lives. https://t.co/zIh6Ol0Tgx

Kenya: "Essential discussions about the election are unfolding on platforms such as Twitter, Facebook, and TikTok. It's on these platforms that crucial civic information--but also disinformation and hate speech--will be amplified." https://t.co/oriMzI2Nvl
"In ergodic literature, nontrivial effort is required to allow the reader to traverse the text." https://t.co/Ewa4o7nQ8q
"I don't need you to interpret and translate my life and my work for other people – sorry journalists, but I’m a shepherd not an idiot." (Nov. 22, 2013) https://t.co/CFwr6QCd9p
“…assumes a paternalistic relationship between science and public..." https://t.co/EuEUqVmwi8
@LizWainwright @tweetbytheriver @RuralWriting “Things that I usually held at arm’s length were beginning to crowd me: buried thoughts, dormant feelings, forgotten experiences.”
When the words stop working, and the institutions, then what? https://t.co/F26AElDLiS
Outlining, a third try at thinking clearly about process, product, and #toolsforthought, growing out of a thread with @ReasonedWriting and @DaveWiner. https://t.co/cN833xnmjR
When writing is going well, organization both precedes and follows content. That's why a person might want to compose right there in the outline. #toolsforthought

If you write about the same thing three days in a row, 1) the focus will likely tighten, 2) the grain of the thinking grow finer, and 3) the organization evolve. I now think that those three things are the same thing, three ways of noticing and naming the process of writing.

@AndySylvester99 I like the principle, the practice, for sure. It reminds me of a collaboration many years ago between dozens of American poets, who all wrote a poem that included the presence of a woman in a black raincoat. It ended up as a book. (Maybe it was red.)

What is an outline? More than one thing . . . https://t.co/PI2HgV4g52
Expanding on a #toolsforthought thread from earlier in the day, where there were several contributions from @ReasonedWriting and @DaveWiner.
I got to learn a good bit about the proper placement of fridges and other support equipment in different kinds of medical facilities over lunch today. https://t.co/r56J6h05QM
https://t.co/gENZpwqUQN
@toebean_peets Decided to delete “near”…
